mods.abstract: Race relations riot that occurred in Memphis in May of 1866. The black population of Memphis had swelled from 4,000 to over 15,000 by 1865. The volatile mix of former slaves or contraband, long-time freedmen of the Beale Street area, four regiments of Colored Troops, the Irish police force, and the suffering poor clashed in South Memphis for several days with the resulting deaths of 44 blacks and two whites and the loss for blacks of 91 houses, 12 schools, and four churches. See Image 2815.

titleInfo.title: Reconstruction and the African American Legacy in Tennessee

relatedItem.abstract: For years, the Reconstruction era marked a tumultuous period in American and Tennessee history. Even before the formal process of Reconstruction began following the Civil War, steps were taken to address the rights of freed slaves and the readmission of Confederate states to the Union. The materials in this collection portray a few of the challenges and victories that emerged during Reconstruction. The focus of the images rests primarily on the Reconstruction period and Gilded Age (1876-1910) in Tennessee following the Civil War.
